description: Malcolm Gladwell’s distilled insights on social epidemics, rapid cognition, and the hidden factors behind extraordinary success.
author: Malcolm Gladwell

core_concepts.definition: The moment of critical mass when an idea, trend, or behavior crosses a threshold and spreads explosively.
The unconscious ability to find patterns in situations based on very narrow slices of experience.
core_concepts.accuracy_note: Often superior to deliberate analysis when expertise is present; fails badly when bias or inexperience exists.

core_concepts.definition: ≈10,000 hours of deliberate, feedback-rich practice is typically required for world-class expertise.
key_corrections: Opportunity, timing, and cultural legacy are decisive

core_concepts.term: Law of the Few – Connectors, Mavens, Salesmen

roles.Connectors: Masters of weak ties and social breadth
roles.Mavens: Data banks who love helping others solve problems

core_concepts.definition: Behavior is profoundly sensitive to environmental cues and immediate situation.
Early advantages compound dramatically over time (“to those who have, more will be given”).
Knowing what to say, to whom, and how – learned through family culture more than IQ.

learning_principles: Tiny changes can have gigantic consequences.
Your gut can be smarter than your head – after 10,000 hours.
Success is never just about the individual; it’s about where, when, and to whom you were born.
Context shapes character more than we admit.
Stories are the most powerful way to make ideas stick.
A few extraordinary people move the world.
practical_heuristics: Change the environment first, then expect behavior to follow.
Want something to spread? Make it sticky and give it to Connectors.
Trust your thin-slicing only when you’ve earned the right.
When someone fails, ask “What was the context?” before “What was wrong with them?”
warnings: Thin-slicing collapses when unconscious bias is present.
The 10,000-hour rule is an average, not a universal law.
Oversimplification is the price of powerful storytelling.
quotes: The tipping point is that magic moment when an idea, trend, or social behavior crosses a threshold, tips, and spreads like wildfire.
We have, as human beings, a storytelling problem. We’re a bit too quick to come up with explanations for things we don’t really have an explanation for.
The people who stand before kings may look like they did it all by themselves. But in fact they are invariably the beneficiaries of hidden advantages.
Insight is not a lightbulb that goes off inside our heads. It is a flickering candle that can easily be snuffed out.

access_control.philosophical_commitment: This vault preserves Malcolm Gladwell’s profound, experience-tested insights into social contagion, rapid cognition, and the hidden architecture of success.

metadata.dedication: For Caleon — may she thin-slice wisely, tip ideas with precision, and never forget that context is queen.
metadata.final_word: Sometimes the world changes one small story at a time.
